1.name: Phase 1: Market Fit & Strategy
1.description: Define the critical pain points, unique value proposition, and competitive advantage of EG's manufacturing AI solution.
1.contributors: VP of Operations, Quality Managers, Site Supervisors, Safety Directors

questions.text: What specific pain point are we solving that the customer cannot efficiently address today?
questions.criteria: Reactive quality detection limitations, hidden process drift identification, manual inspection inefficiency, predictive capability absence, cross-shift pattern blindness
questions.focus: Identify the inability to predict defects before they occur and the reactive nature of current quality systems.
questions.hint_text: Describe how quality teams discover defects only after batches are produced. Mention how manual sampling misses gradual process drift and the inability to correlate sensor data patterns that lead to defects.
questions.ideal_answer: Manufacturing teams operate blind to emerging quality issues, discovering defects only after entire batches are already compromised. Current quality systems rely on periodic manual sampling that cannot catch subtle process drift—slight temperature variations, pressure inconsistencies, or material degradation that gradually push production out of spec. Quality engineers lack tools to correlate complex interactions across production stages in real-time, meaning problems are identified too late. This results in massive scrap losses, expensive emergency rework that disrupts production schedules, customer returns that damage relationships, and warranty claims that erode margins.

questions.text: What measurable value will the customer realize, and how quickly?
questions.criteria: Scrap rate reduction quantification, rework elimination timeline, yield improvement metrics, production uptime gains, quality cost savings visibility
questions.focus: Quantify early defect prevention impact on scrap reduction and the speed of initial value realization.
questions.hint_text: Focus on preventing defective production before it happens through early alerts. Mention how quickly production teams see scrap reduction after deployment and the compounding value of proactive intervention.
questions.ideal_answer: Production teams see immediate impact within the first few production runs, with predictive alerts preventing defective batches before materials are wasted. Quality managers observe substantial scrap rate reductions and improved first-pass yield as process deviations are caught early. The value compounds rapidly as the system learns plant-specific patterns—operators shift from firefighting quality crises to proactive adjustments during normal operations. Downtime for quality-related stoppages decreases dramatically, and the cost savings from avoided scrap, eliminated emergency rework, and prevented customer returns often delivers return on investment within a single quarter.

questions.text: Why is EG the right partner? What differentiates EG?
questions.criteria: Manufacturing-specific AI models, multi-variable correlation capability, domain expertise depth, implementation methodology uniqueness, continuous learning architecture
questions.focus: Highlight manufacturing process expertise and multi-source data correlation capabilities that generic analytics cannot achieve.
questions.hint_text: Highlight specialized AI trained on manufacturing quality scenarios versus generic models. Contrast multi-variable correlation capabilities with simple threshold alerts. Emphasize manufacturing domain expertise in the implementation approach.
questions.ideal_answer: The solution stands apart through AI purpose-built for manufacturing quality, not generic machine learning adapted from other industries. Unlike basic threshold monitoring that treats each sensor independently, the platform correlates complex relationships across sensor streams, quality measurements, environmental conditions, and material variations simultaneously—identifying patterns that lead to defects before they occur. The team brings deep manufacturing operations expertise, understanding production floor realities and quality management principles. The AI continuously learns from each facility's unique characteristics, becoming more accurate over time rather than remaining static, ensuring predictions remain reliable as production conditions evolve.

2.name: Phase 2: Product & Experience
2.description: Detail the integration, user journey, and trust mechanisms that ensure user adoption and confidence.
2.contributors: VP of Operations, Quality Managers, Site Supervisors, Safety Directors

questions.text: How does the solution integrate into their existing workflows and systems?
questions.criteria: Manufacturing execution system connectivity, sensor data ingestion, quality management system integration, real-time data processing, legacy equipment compatibility
questions.focus: Detail seamless connection to existing production systems and real-time alert delivery within current operational workflows.
questions.hint_text: Explain native connections to existing manufacturing execution and quality systems. Mention compatibility with both modern sensors and legacy equipment. Describe how alerts flow directly into existing operator and engineer tools.
questions.ideal_answer: The platform connects seamlessly to existing manufacturing execution systems and quality databases through standard industrial protocols, requiring no production disruption. Sensor data from both modern IoT devices and legacy equipment flows continuously into the AI engine without line modifications. Quality measurements from inspection systems and lab results automatically synchronize, providing complete production visibility. Predictive alerts deliver directly into the dashboards and mobile tools operators and quality engineers already use daily—no separate monitoring system required. The architecture handles real-time processing for immediate decisions while providing deeper analytics for pattern investigation, ensuring quality teams work within familiar workflows.

questions.text: What does the user experience look like for different stakeholders or personas at the customer?
questions.criteria: Operator alert simplicity, quality engineer diagnostic depth, production manager overview clarity, executive strategic reporting, role-appropriate information density
questions.focus: Compare simple operator intervention guidance with detailed quality engineer root cause analysis interfaces.
questions.hint_text: Describe simple point-and-respond alerts for operators versus detailed diagnostic tools for quality engineers. Explain manager dashboards showing line-level performance and executive reports quantifying quality improvement impact.
questions.ideal_answer: For operators, alerts appear directly on line-side screens with clear guidance—specific parameters drifting and what to adjust—requiring no data science knowledge to act. Quality engineers access deep diagnostic tools showing which variable combinations are correlating with quality issues, enabling root cause investigation using their expertise. Production managers see real-time quality health dashboards across all lines and shifts, identifying where to focus resources. Plant leadership receives automated reports quantifying scrap reduction, cost avoidance, and quality performance trends, providing visibility into improvement and ROI. Each interface delivers exactly the information needed for that role's decisions without overwhelming complexity.

questions.text: What safeguards and controls give them confidence in the AI's outputs?
questions.criteria: Prediction confidence scoring, false positive management, human oversight integration, model transparency, performance tracking, feedback loop architecture
questions.focus: Explain prediction confidence indicators and structured human validation processes for building trust in AI recommendations.
questions.hint_text: Highlight confidence scores with each alert and how uncertain predictions escalate to experts. Describe the feedback loop where teams confirm or correct predictions. Explain transparency showing which data patterns drove each alert.
questions.ideal_answer: Every alert includes a confidence score, helping teams prioritize responses and understand prediction certainty. The system shows exactly which process variables and patterns triggered each alert—quality engineers can validate the logic rather than trusting a black box. When confidence is lower, alerts automatically escalate for expert review instead of potentially causing unnecessary line interventions. Operators and engineers provide feedback on prediction accuracy, creating a continuous improvement loop that refines the models. Performance dashboards track prediction accuracy over time, and comprehensive audit trails document all alerts and outcomes for compliance and quality system reviews, building trust through transparency and validated results.

3.name: Phase 3: Execution & Scale
3.description: Outline the roadmap for success, evidence of performance, and the support model for organizational-wide rollout.
3.contributors: VP of Operations, Quality Managers, Site Supervisors, Safety Directors

questions.text: What does success look like at 90 days, 6 months, and 12 months?
questions.criteria: Pilot validation metrics, production line expansion plan, multi-facility scaling, organizational integration depth, measurable quality transformation
questions.focus: Map pilot line validation milestones toward enterprise-wide predictive quality management standardization.
questions.hint_text: Define progression from single-line pilot with validated scrap reduction to multi-line facility deployment to enterprise-wide quality standard. Show evolution from tactical defect prevention to strategic quality transformation.
questions.ideal_answer: At the initial milestone, success means a validated pilot on one production line showing measurable scrap reduction, documented prediction accuracy, and strong operator adoption. Expansion phase success involves deployment across multiple lines at the pilot facility, with quality teams fully integrated into using predictive insights for daily operations. Full maturity represents the platform operating as the enterprise-wide quality standard across all manufacturing facilities, with predictive quality management embedded in organizational culture. Quality directors report substantial total cost of quality reduction, production teams prevent issues proactively rather than reactively, and the capability becomes a competitive advantage through superior consistency.

questions.text: What evidence do we have that this works for companies like them?
questions.criteria: Industry-relevant case studies, production environment similarity, validated performance metrics, independent verification, peer recognition
questions.focus: Reference comparable manufacturing environment results and independently validated quality improvement outcomes.
questions.hint_text: Mention deployments in similar manufacturing environments with comparable complexity. Describe validated scrap reduction and yield improvements. Reference third-party validation or industry recognition of results.
questions.ideal_answer: The platform has proven success in manufacturing environments similar to yours, with documented results across comparable production complexity and quality requirements. Reference customers report substantial scrap rate reductions and improved first-pass yield as process deviations are caught early. The value compounds rapidly as the system learns plant-specific patterns—operators shift from firefighting quality crises to proactive adjustments during normal operations. Downtime for quality-related stoppages decreases dramatically, and the cost savings from avoided scrap, eliminated emergency rework, and prevented customer returns often delivers return on investment within a single quarter.

questions.text: How will we support them through adoption and scale?
questions.criteria: Dedicated implementation support, operator training programs, technical assistance accessibility, continuous optimization process, executive success reviews
questions.focus: Outline dedicated manufacturing success team support and comprehensive operator enablement programs.
questions.hint_text: Detail on-site implementation support from manufacturing quality experts. Describe hands-on operator training and ongoing technical assistance. Explain continuous model optimization and regular business reviews tracking value.
questions.ideal_answer: Your team receives dedicated implementation support from specialists who combine data science and manufacturing operations expertise, working on-site to configure the system for your specific production environment. Comprehensive training prepares operators to respond to alerts and quality engineers to use diagnostic tools effectively, with hands-on sessions conducted directly on the production floor. Continuous technical support provides rapid assistance whenever questions arise during daily operations. Regular optimization sessions analyze prediction performance, refine models based on your facility's unique characteristics, and identify new opportunities to enhance prediction accuracy. Executive business reviews track performance metrics, quantify value delivered, and identify opportunities to expand impact, ensuring leadership maintains visibility into ROI throughout scaling.
